I decided against entering the LJ writing contest I was looking at.  There's just too much commitment required there and I am working hard on a publishing schedule now.  Yeah, that's where I've been.  Publishing books.  How about that?  Didn't think that would ever happen.

It's a lot more work than I thought it would be, though!  There's the writing, which is the best part, obviously.  But then there's editing.  Reading.  Editing again. Re-reading. Tweaking.  Sharing with beta.  Tweaking.  Editing.  Re-reading again.  Editing some more.  Re-re-reading.  Make Cover. Tweaking and twitching.  Editing chapter seven. Re-writing chapter ten through eighteen.  Sharing with beta again.  Staring blankly at the wall while I recite chapter three's dialogue, again. Remake cover.  Tweaking.  Handing over to editor with fear in my eyes.  Tweaking and editing based on editor's suggestions.  Reading again.  Editing that funny bit in chapter twelve.  Nervous breakdown.  Editing again.  Tweaking.  Twerking. Fiddle with cover one last time.  Begging Beta to look at this scene again, PLEEEEASE!  Final edits.  Reading again and sighing in relief at the sheer perfection.  Formatting for publishing.  Swearing.  Doing formatting steps again.  Waiting.  Waiting.  Happy dance when book goes live on Amazon, Smashwords, & Lulu.  Take day off to gorge on sleep and candy.  And finally, start again!

I always laughed a little when people said that it takes a love of writing and sharing your stories that knows no bounds to be an author.  Now I laugh, but with the tired laugh of a person who knows it to be true.  Though, it's all worth it when I log into my Amazon KDP account and see that someone in Germany or Australia bought one of our books.  It really is.

My entire life is built on second chances.   The closest friendships of my life are the people that I've fallen out with and who I gave a second (or third or forth) chance and who gave it to me.  One of the happiest days of my life was when I begged my life partner to give us another chance after the horrible misunderstanding that broke us up before we had even had a chance to get together properly.  and my closest friends are people that I stopped talking to, in some cases for years, for no good reason and we all gave each other a second chance.  I think that there can a great value in letting the people you are really connected to have that one more shot at being a part of your life.   I know that without second chances, I would be a very sad lonely person today because of the mistakes and misunderstandings of youth.

And I know that there are some people who used to be very important in my life (former friends, family members and random people I have crossed paths with who aren't quite friends but who touched my life none the less) and they could never consider giving a second chance or opening thier hearts again and forgiving the mistakes that were made or the poor judgments made about people.  That makes me a little sad inside, not because my life is missing something without them or I think thier lives are miserable and incomplete without me.  But because I have learned that when you open your heart to forgive and give a second chance to the other people in your life, you are able to give yourself a second chance too.

It's so important that you are able to create that chance in your life, the permission to stop your self destructive habits and let yourself have a second chance.  A clean slate so to speak.  There is a point in all our lives where being able to forgive the mistakes of our pasts frees us to create a new future.  One where we aren't wieghed down with the guilt and regret and self-loathing that goes along with dragging all your mistakes along thru life like a great weight tied to our souls.

anyway, below is the letter that they have on the site to send out to all your friends via email and encourage them to sign the petition.  I don't have many friends but I do hope that the ones I have will repost this and get as many signatures on the petition as possible.

So who doesn't like RPGs? That's right, all us geeks just love us some good old RP-ing. But let's be honest, the best part is making the character right? And there are a million and one methods to do it. With this meme I am taking two of my favourite things and making them into one great meme! So warm up your music player of choice, get your randomizer out and let's make some characters for our imaginary RP!!

Here's what you do: set player to random, list the first 11 songs that come up. Take each song and use it to fill in the categories as listed below. You can be creative and have fun with it! (get your songs before you look at the list! It's more fun that way!) There are no rules. The world you are playing in has no set reference points, but this is meant to be a parody based meme so going with the old cliques of sword and sorcery are OK, encouraged in fact!

Now that you have a character, encourage your F List to play too by reposting this entry with your answers in the place of mine!

And who knows, I might create a forum for facing off with our cracked characters. You never know what I might do, lol.

(PS -- please credit me when you repost, I worked hard on making this just right)

 


 

1 Name what will we call you? remember RP characters have completely ridiculous names, so sometimes just the title of the song or the band name is enough. Or the best words in the song (I pity you if you have a FOB or PATD song) if all else fails, reverse the order of the letters of either title or artist!

2 Social Status this is a little harder to define, but it could also be called your class or your place in the society you character comes from. prince, pauper, teacher, fry cook. whatever fits the song!
3 Affiliation do you have a club? or are you a loner? feel free to create a guild, after school club or PTA committee that you belong to.
4 Special skill your stupid human trick of the RP world.
5 weapon of choice 45 caliber, sword, club, wit, rubber chicken?
6 most powerful attack first choice for ass kickings?
7 best defense must. not. die.
8 Companion you just might have to drag someone along with you. is it your lover? or your parakeet? or a volleyball that you maimed and named?
9 Merit one of your good traits. try and see the positive side of your song.
10 Flaw your bad habit or annoying tick that will inevitably be your downfall.
11 Dark Secret what will eventually get your memoirs in Oprah's book club and fuel your talk show tour.

5 Helpful Hints from Hermie:
Writing Advice (nov 2008)

November is National Novel Writing Month, and who doesn't want to write a novel?  Sounds like great plan, but then you sit down to write something and all you get is the gibberish that comes from banging your head on the keyboard or a notebook full of doodles and grocery lists.  So how do you take a desire to write a novel and turn it into one? 

The answer is simple.  You write it.  Just sit down and do it.  Easier said than done you say?  Not so.  The first step, the greatest one you can take in writing anything, is making that first effort to convey your thoughts from brain to paper or computer screen.  Once you have overcome that initial hurdle the rest will come to you. 

Remember that J.R.R. Tolkien started his epic tales of the Hobbit and Lord of the Rings with a single sentence.  "There was once a Hobbit that lived in a hole."  He didn't even know what a Hobbit was or why the damned thing lived in a hole, but from that single sentence one of the greatest works of fiction was born.


Tip # 1 -- Don't Call It A Novel.  When you call your work a novel, then you have to divide it into perfectly sequential chapters and have so many pages, and format it just so.  You are going to give yourself nightmares getting the chapter headings in the right places.  Call it your writing, your story, your adventure.  Once you remove the pressures of the word 'novel' you are able to open the creative floodgates that won't be constrained by logical divides of chapters, page counts or anything else that makes it a novel.  Now that you aren't expecting yourself to do more than tell the story, you can get to the telling.

Tip # 2 --  Just write it.  Editing comes later.    The thing that snags most of us up in the writing process is going back and languishing over a turn of phrase, or a word we just can't spell to save our lives.  A writer could get stuck on the same sentence for days if you are trying to get it just perfect.  Instead of worrying over the details, typos, and lame flat phrasing, just write it.  Get words out of your head and on to the page.  Don't worry about writing it in order, don't worry about it being the greatest thing ever written.  This is what we call a first draft.  It's not going to look or feel like the books you pick up at the bookstore.  But not a one of them just sprung into being in it's shiny finished form.  Every book that you have ever picked up, started out in the same place.  As a beautifully flawed first draft.

Tip # 3 --  Don't Edit until you are DONE.  If you start the editing process before the story is told, you will find yourself second guessing your raw writing when it's time to produce some new material.  Just set your work aside as you create it, and wait until you are done to go back and edit it.  One of the most successful techniques I have is taking a couple days off when the story is done before picking it back up for editing.  That gives your mind a couple days to calm down and distances you from the crazy raw process of creating the first draft.

Tip # 4  --  Make Time to Write.  Set aside a time during your day where you can focus on your writing.  When your kids are quiet, the dog is napping and your real world problems are set aside for the day.  Make a point to give yourself the some time every day!   Even if it's just 20 minutes in the car while you wait for the kids to get out of school or 45 minutes while dinner is in the oven.   If you can, make a ritual out of it.  Make your favourite cup of tea, have a special pen you use or a special pair of pajamas you wear.  What ever it takes to tell your mind, and the people around you that you are ready to write and focus on your story.  It may take you a few tries to discover what works for you.   Some people have to go to a special place.  J.K. Rowling did all her writing on yellow legal pads in a local coffee shop for her Harry Potter books.  Robert Kineck (children's book author) spends his first 20 minutes of every morning writing, to capture the ideas while they are fresh.  Every writer has a unique voice and therefore a unique process to their writing.  Find your place, time, process.

Tip # 5 --  Never Leave Home Without a Notebook.   Ideas have a funny way of attacking you in the middle of the supermarket, at a red light, as you are having a latte at lunchtime.  They are unruly creatures who don't like to follow the rules you try and establish for them.  You will find that creating a special time and place for writing helps to tame them, gives an outlet where they can be caught and contained on the page, however wild bursts of inspiration do attack when it is least convenient.  Carrying a small notebook and a pen/pencil with you lets you have a way to capture and contain them until it's time to put them to work in your usual writing time.  Any one who is a creative person of any sort could benefit from this tip!   A half sized sketch book for artists can sometimes be a blessing too!  Carry this notebook in your purse, pocket, planner, or in my case, spiffy anime messenger bag.  Even guys can carry a messenger bag (or the oh so sexy man-purse!) and not look out of place. 

Hope my tips help!  And if you want to see some more tips next month, feel free to send me a message with comments, questions or tips of your own that I can use in the next installment!
